explanation:
The target function's only controlling expression is the if test: (NULL == resp). To decide if that controlling expression is invariant (always true or always false) we must know what value resp can take at run time — i.e. the return behaviour of the function that produces it and any inputs that affect that behaviour.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: resp is assigned from this call. You must inspect its implementation or contract to see whether it can ever return NULL (or conversely always returns a valid pointer). If this function is effectively a constant-return function in the build (always NULL or always non-NULL), the if condition would be invariant.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls: the static call graph shows the above function delegates to this helper. Its implementation may contain the logic (allocation, validation) that determines whether a response object is created or NULL is returned. Inspecting it is necessary to fully understand possible return values of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static.

- MAIN_PAGE: page_content and page_content_len (derived from MAIN_PAGE) are passed to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static. The content pointer/length can affect the behaviour of the create function (e.g. it may return NULL for zero-length content or treat particular inputs specially). To conclude invariance you must know whether the value of MAIN_PAGE (and thus page_content_len) can cause the create function to deterministically return NULL or non-NULL.

(Other calls in the function such as MHD_add_response_header, MHD_queue_response and MHD_destroy_response do not influence the controlling expression and therefore are not required for this specific MISRA invariant check.)
